title: Arco Primo vs Arco Doppio
comparison_headline: Ready to upgrade, but not sure how far to go?
comparison_intro: The Primo is where most people start their espresso journey, and it does that job beautifully. The Doppio is where you land when you want temperature stability, simultaneous steaming, and the kind of consistency that makes you stop blaming the beans.
hero_image_alt: Arco Primo and Arco Doppio espresso machines side by side on a light marble countertop, the Primo in matte white and the Doppio in brushed steel, two freshly pulled espresso shots in matching ceramic cups between them, soft natural light from a kitchen window

pressure_control.product_a: 15 bar pump (9 bar at group), fixed OPV
pressure_control.product_b: Rotary vane pump, adjustable OPV (6–10 bar)

steam_capability.product_a: Single boiler — must switch between brew and steam modes
steam_capability.product_b: Dedicated steam boiler — brew and steam simultaneously

grind_compatibility.product_a: Works well with stepped grinders like the Macinino
grind_compatibility.product_b: Benefits from a stepless grinder like the Preciso for fine-tuning

suitable_for.product_a: People who want a quick, reliable morning espresso without complexity
suitable_for.product_b: People ready to explore latte art, temperature surfing is behind them, and consistency matters

not_suitable_for.product_a: Anyone who makes milk drinks frequently — the single boiler creates a wait between brewing and steaming
not_suitable_for.product_b: Anyone who values a 90-second heat-up over temperature precision — the Doppio needs 3 minutes

morning-minimalist.rationale: The Primo heats up faster and keeps your morning simple — if your routine is one black espresso and out the door, it does everything you need.

upgrader.rationale: If you have been frustrated by temperature inconsistency or waiting between shots and steaming, the Doppio solves both problems immediately.

non-barista.rationale: Fewer settings and faster heat-up mean fewer ways to get confused — the Primo is forgiving in a way the Doppio is not.

craft-barista.rationale: The adjustable OPV and dual PID give you the control to actually dial in — the Primo is a great machine, but it will limit you quickly.

verdict: If you drink straight espresso and value speed above all else, the Primo is an excellent machine that will serve you well for years. But if you have started to notice inconsistency in your shots, want to make milk drinks without the wait, or simply want room to grow, the Doppio is the smarter long-term investment. The price gap is real, but so is the daily difference in workflow.
